awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Study of Ice Deformation under Tidal Loading Conditions with Application to Antarctic Glaciers
awd_abstract_narration:
1245871/McCarthy


This award supports a project to conduct laboratory experiments with a new, custom-fabricated cryo-friction apparatus to explore ice deformation oscillatory stresses like those experienced by tidewater glaciers in nature.  The experimental design will explore the dynamic frictional properties of periodically loaded ice sliding on rock. Although the frictional strength of ice has been studied in the past these studies have all focused on constant rates of loading and sliding.  The results of this work will advance understanding of ice stream dynamics by improving constraints on key material and frictional properties and allowing physics-based predictions of the amplitude and phase of glacier strain due to tidally induced stress variations. The intellectual merit of this work is that it will result in a better understanding of dynamic rheological parameters and will provide better predictive tools for dynamic glacier flow. The proposed experiments will provide dynamic material properties of ice and rock deformation at realistic frequencies experienced by Antarctic glaciers. The PIs will measure the full spectrum of material response from elastic to anelastic to viscous. The study will provide better constraints to improve predictive capability for glacier and ice-stream response to external forcing.   The broader impacts of the work include providing estimates of material properties that can be used to broaden our understanding of glacier flow and that will ultimately be used for models of sea level rise and ice sheet stability. The ability to predict sea level in the near future is contingent on understanding of the processes responsible for flow of Antarctic ice streams and glaciers. Modulation of glacier flow by ocean tides represents a natural experiment that can be used to improve knowledge of ice and bed properties, and of the way in which these properties depend on time-varying forcings. Presently, the influence of tidal forcing on glacier movement is poorly understood, and knowledge of ice properties under tidal loading conditions is limited. The study will generate results of interest beyond polar science by examining phenomena that are of interest to seismology, glaciology and general materials science. The project will provide valuable research and laboratory experience for two undergraduate interns and will provide experience for the PI (currently a postdoc) in leading a scientific project. The three PIs are early career scientists. This proposal does not require fieldwork in the Antarctic.

por.por_cntn:
For this grant, our major goal and activity was to explore ice deformation systematically under tidal loading conditions using a custom-fabricated cryo-friction apparatus. To that end, our activities followed a necessary progression. Since this was the first study using this apparatus, we first calibrated it by testing the friction and creep responses of known standards and documenting all of the limits. We built a removable cryostat that allows for loading of the sample in a cold room and transporting to the apparatus, where it is mounted and temperature within is monitored by multiple thermocouples. The details of the apparatus and cryostat, as well as the experimental results from the plastic standards and preliminary ice friction and creep tests, were written into a paper in the Review of Scientific Instruments [McCarthy et al., 2016].

After fully characterizing the rig, we began a series of experiments designed to isolate individual physical properties at steady state. The first of these was to measure friction systematically as a function of temperature and velocity. We employed the traditional rock mechanics tests to measure rate-state parameters. These results were written into a special ice volume of the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Academy [McCarthy et al., 2017]. The constitutive equations for friction determined from this study, which include the temperature dependence of both steady-state friction and healing at high homologous temperatures, provide valuable parameters for models of glacier and ice stream sliding. The physics of ice friction explored here also provide fundamental information about rock friction at high homologous temperature (as might be the case in high velocity seismic sliding) that are not possible in current rock friction studies.

We additionally developed detailed techniques for fabricating and characterizing samples and sliding surfaces. Through trial and error, a multi-step method for creating reproducible pore-free, impurity-free, rectangular samples of “standard ice” with uniform grain size was developed. Sliding surfaces were roughened and the roughness was quantified with a profilometer before and after testing. A specifically designated cold room microscope and microtome were used to characterize samples before and after frictional testing.

Finally we conducted periodic tests designed to determine the frequency and amplitude dependences of the ice frictional response. We used a periodic driving force and measured directly the friction response. In a single experiment we were able to observe a transition between stable sliding and stick-slip regimes. By testing a range of frequencies we determined the critical frequency above which failure occurs at maximum stress rather than maximum stressing rate, and determined whether this frequency scales to tidal ranges. In addition to informing our knowledge of glacier sliding, these are the first friction experiments that span both the unstable and stable sliding regimes under oscillating loads. We anticipate at least one paper on the application of these results to the wide variety of tidal responses shown by glaciers in Antarctica and elsewhere. Ultimately, these results will contribute to the improved understanding of complex glacier dynamics needed to improve predictions of sea-level rise.
